clinical_study.brief_title: Soft Coagulation for the Prevention of Adenoma Recurrence
clinical_study.official_title: Soft Coagulation for the Prevention of Adenoma Recurrence After Endoscopic Mucosal Resection (EMR) of Large Sessile Colonic Polyps: A Multicentre, Randomized Trial.

lead_sponsor.agency: South West Sydney Local Health District

clinical_study.source: South West Sydney Local Health District

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose is to investigate whether a simple additional treatment applied during colonoscopy (called 'soft' coagulation) can reduce the risk of recurrence of polyp at the area where the polyp was removed. After a large polyp is removed it is known that there is a 20% chance that a small recurrence of polyp occurs at the site of removal can occur within 5 months of the polyp being removed. This in theory will burn off tiny polyp tissue, which is usually not visible to the naked eye. This additional treatment may possibly reduce the risk of polyp recurrence.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.measure: Reduced rates of recurrence following EMR

secondary_outcome.measure: Compare previous rates of adenoma recurrence prior to initation of this treatment to recurrence rates of adenomas following initiation of this study.

arm_group.description: Patients do not receive Snare Tip Soft Coagulation to the edges of resected tissue.
Patients to receive Snare Tip Soft Coagulation to the resected edges.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Referred for removal of a colonic polyps <20mm
Exclusion Criteria:
- Younger than 18 years of age
- Highly dependant on medical care
- Women who are pregnant or may be pregnant.
